metadata.title: AMD Zodiac
aws::graph::propositions: AMD Zodiac Aircraft Accidents and Safety Measures
An amateur-built CH-601XL broke up in flight over Arkansas on 6 November 2009.
The pilot of the amateur-built CH-601XL died in the 6 November 2009 accident.
Both wings of the amateur-built CH-601XL separated in flight during the 6 November 2009 accident.
The 6 November 2009 accident revealed a failure mode similar to earlier crashes.
The 6 November 2009 accident brought the total number of crashes to seven.
The 6 November 2009 accident brought the total number of deaths to eleven.
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) issued a Special Airworthiness Information Bulletin on 7 November 2009.
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) strongly recommended that the aircraft not be flown until modifications were carried out.
The modifications were detailed in an Aircraft Manufacturing and Development (AMD) Safety Alert.
Aircraft Manufacturing and Development (AMD) issued documents on 7 November 2009.
Zenith Aircraft issued documents on 7 November 2009.
Aircraft Manufacturing and Development (AMD) mandated that the Special Light-Sport Aircraft (S-LSA) version not be flown until modifications were completed.
Zenith Aircraft mandated that the Special Light-Sport Aircraft (S-LSA) version not be flown until modifications were completed.
Aircraft Manufacturing and Development (AMD) recommended all aircraft be modified.
Zenith Aircraft recommended all aircraft be modified.
The modifications included strengthening of the main wing spar carrythroughs.
The modifications included strengthening of the rear wing spar carrythroughs.
The modifications included the addition of aileron balance weights.
The Experimental Aircraft Association recommended grounding all affected aircraft until modifications are complete.

text:
On 6 November 2009, an amateur-built CH-601XL broke up in flight over Arkansas, resulting in the death of the pilot. Preliminary investigation of the accident revealed a failure mode similar to that seen in the earlier crashes, as both wings separated in flight. This brought the number of crashes to seven and deaths to 11.
The FAA issued a Special Airworthiness Information Bulletin on 7 November 2009 and strongly recommended that the aircraft not be flown until modifications detailed in an AMD Safety Alert are carried out. AMD and Zenith Aircraft issued documents the same day, mandating that the S-LSA version not be flown until the modifications were completed and recommended all aircraft be modified. The modifications included strengthening of the main and rear wing spar carrythroughs and the addition of aileron balance weights. The Experimental Aircraft Association also recommended grounding all affected aircraft until modifications are complete.
